Second, when a checker has made it across the board, it is not "kinged" to return to play, but instead remains in the "King's Row."*** At the end of the game, the player who can put together the best poker hand from the checkers that have traversed the board wins the game.

This game is something of a mystery. It comes in a Monopoly-sized box, with a heavy board and very heavy-duty checkers, but no publisher or designer is listed on the game.


Correction: a checker in the King's Row may be moved out of King's Row to remove opponent's pieces, but may not be compelled to do so. Only the checkers that are in King's Row at the end of the game are counted.
categories: Abstract Strategy

name: Memphis-opoly
description:
A board game about the GREAT city of Memphis! We chose some favorite landmarks and traditions, mixed in some bar-b-que, great music, Graceland, the arts, and some BIG FUN... and voilà (vwä lä)-behold; MEMPHIS-OPOLY! Grab Some Friends and
Gather 'Round!

Here's a quick idea of how to play! Buy property, collect City Blocks and trade in for a Key to the City. It sounds easy enough - but add in a traffic jam, property taxes, parking tickets and the IRS and it becomes a little more difficult... and a lot more FUN!

Get YOUR Game On, Memphis! It's Your Roll!

Publisher's Website
categories: Economic, Negotiation
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Орки идут! (The Orcs are Coming!)
description:
Children’s game about humans, dwarves and orcs. Humans and dwarves lived in peace when the tribes of malicious orcs came and started to assault the civilians. Then humans entered into alliance with dwarves and began to protect their homes.

The alliance’s goal is to destroy all the enemies, while the orcs are to do the same with their opponents. (From the rulebook)

The game appears to have a main "story" (scenario), which is what you get in the big box, and you can then purchase other "stories" in the smaller boxes. The large set includes:


Warrior figures: Allies - 12 pcs., Orcs - 7 pcs.
Playing field - 1 pc.
Game rules - 1 pc.
Cube D6 - 2 pcs.
Tokens (round):


"Ashes" - 23 pcs.,
"Orcs. 1 life" - 6 pcs.,
"Allies. 1 life" - 7 pcs.

Tokens (square):


"Orcs. Equipment" - 4 pcs.,
"Allies. Equipment" - 4 pcs.

Equipment Token Reminder
Unique Cells Reminder
categories: Children's Game, Fantasy

name: Penguin Stack
description: Preschool dexterity game where players take turns adding different size blocks to a stack. If the players successfully add all the blocks the penguin is rescued.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game
publishers: (Looking for a publisher), Happy Squash Toys

name: Color-Coded
description:
In this color decoding, star gathering, trick playing game you gotta be the first to match your various colored Star Cards with the Code dealt and use special PLAY cards, switch abilities and Black Wild cards to change the round in your favor. Obtain five wins and the game is yours!

Color-Coded is simple to learn! Each player is given a specific code of colored stars they need to match using the colored cards in their hand. Match the code and you move on to the next, match five and you win the game!

There are special cards to help tip the balance in your favor. Use the Black Wild Cards which can be used for any card in your code. PLAY cards grant abilities like switching, trading, and even destroying your other players hand and code! When nothing else can be done, you can at least tempt fate by using SWITCH, which forces all players to choose a card from their hands and pass it to their left, maybe the card you need is just around the corner?

The best part is no matter where you are in the game, additional people can join in the fun! Simply deal then a hand and give him a code. Who knows, the winner may have just arrived!


of Players: 2-6


Game Time: 45 min.

Includes:
* Star Cards Deck (80 cards)
* Code Cards Deck (40 cards)
* Color-Coded Rules Document
categories: Card Game

name: Fallen Shadow
description:
Falling Shadow is the first expansion for MageStorm.In this set you will find two new, powerful mages: the Water Mage, wielding the healing power of this life-giving element, and the Dark Mage, drawing his power from the realms of frost and shadow.

Both new mages can be combined with the existing human and elven armies to increase the number of playable combinations to 12 and will be featured prominently in the new and included scenarios.

The mages will be presented with their own mage boards and the accompanying counters, token and markers.

Source:Nexus Spring catalog 2010
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Secret Unit Deployment, Variable Player Powers

name: Funny Little Wars
description:
Subtitle: Being In The Main a Preoccupation For The Better Sort of Chap, & Making Full Use of Classic Toy Soldiers (Which The Pedants Call "54mm")

Publisher's description:

Written in part as a tribute to HG Wells ground breaking Little Wars , FLW is a much expanded and broadened modernization. There is a fascinating chapter devoted to Wells the Man and his journey with his "Little Wars" from inception to the day in 1916 when he put the game away for good. For fans of Wells' work, The Padre may surprise you with information you did not know, or could even guess.

Retaining many of Wells' original rules (such as the use of spring-loaded toy cannon), there are now additional rules for Shell Bursts, machine guns, observation balloons and aircraft, field hospitals, supply wagons and dumps, spies, military bands, unit Colors and Standards, Brigade up to Division Commands, hidden movement, skirmishers, snipers, unpredictable effects of terrain, signals, morale, and much more.

Infantry units are a standard 20 figures strong, Cavalry 12, and Artillery can appear as single Guns with crews, or as Batteries of up to three strong. From two to four such units, with a Battery, typically form a Brigade, the perfect command for each Player. Two or more Brigades form a Division, and this is the post for the Player who will act as Commanding Officer for his side.

Each Brigade and the Divisional HQ is represented by a variable number of Staff and ADC's, marching on foot, mounted on prancing steeds, or even seated in Rolls Royce, Cadillac, Renault, or other grand Staff Cars from the Golden Age of Motoring. From these HQ's must come the orders to the units on the firing line, but the traffic isn't all one way! Back to the Brigadiers and the Commanding General, come the reports of the scouts--and the desperate messages from the front lines delivered by Runners, Gallopers, and even Pigeons! There is far more skill than luck required to lead your miniature minions to victory, and the rules provide this without complicated systems. In many respects, there is far less abstraction in Funny Little Wars in the spaces of your garden than there is on the traditional table top.

While designed for yard games, the rules can be played on the floor or table top. Figures used can range from antique and modern "Collectibles," to readily available plastics. Included are detailed lists for 14 different Armies identified by their "Colors," ("Army Red," "Army Black," "Army Red/Gold," etc) with complete information on how to build your favorites. Each Army has its unique strengths and weaknesses, and a personality which will definitely suggest its historical counterpart.

Much as Wells' rules did, FLW covers the quarter century prior to WW I, when war was still romantic, the uniforms were dashing, and the Generals still waltzed. This is the very era that gave birth to the Military Pentathalon, and a player may find himself having to excel in one or more of its challenges to deliver a crucial dispatch! Padre Paul's rules reflect the late Victorian and Edwardian spirit in both the substance of the rules and the delightful style of his writing. Designed for "The Better Sort of Chap," the book contains suggestions for proper Dress during the game, etiquette on the field, and more. Nor are the Ladies and "Girls of the better sort" forgotten. The Padre's Wife, Georgina, provides a charming account of a "proper dinner" served after an especially Gentlemanly game at Dover Castle one recent Summer.

Not only are there the Basic Rules, but many Optional Rules allowing players to set their own levels of play. There are lists of providers of toy soldiers in every price range, as well as all manner of accessories, and recommendations on how to shop inexpensively on the Internet for those items you will not find so readily in the stores. Sections describe how to set up a yard, park, rockery, beach, or other site to be your Battlefield. For once, you WILL have room to perform that wide flanking maneuver! Light Cavalry and Infantry come into their own, screening your forces while trying to detect your enemy's. Once more, War Gaming is as much fun as when any of us discovered the hobby, no matter how many years--or decades!--ago.

Rules for basing figures are flexible and encourage players to work with what is best for their needs. And while comprehensive, there are no complex rules or formulae, and nothing more than traditional six-sided dice are required--besides measuring tapes and a beautiful day under the shade of the trees. Childlike, but never "Childish," FLW goes back to the Hobby's roots, and even our own as we play once more with the toy soldiers so many us first had as kids.
categories: Fighting, Miniatures

name: Pool
description:
3 to 8 persons can play Pool, a game above consumption and how you can make the most with your money.
You have three different lines around the board. J is the Junggeselle (unmarried man), P is partnership (family) and W is a Wohngemeinschaft (apartment-sharing community). You play the J-line alone, the P-line with another player together, the W-Line with two other players together. Every move must be with one consent, otherwise you have to pay 100 money to the bank.
You start at Friday, the game takes 7 days with 6 sections every day. On the board are chance fields and chance cards. Something you can do alone, other decision you can only do with other players together. In this way you increase or losing your money and the player wins with the biggest money.
categories: Dice

name: The Gary's Game
description:
From the rules

Welcome to the world of Gary's Games and Hobbies -- in a card game!

Ever wondered what kind of people hang out at a game store and play games? Have you ever thought about what that might be like?

Well wonder no more! The Gary's Game will let you experience the excitement and drama from your own home with your own friends.

User Summary

Climbing game, similar to The Great Dalmuti or Pyramid Card or Scum: The Food Chain Game or Deathtrap Dungeon: Card Game or Dilbert: Corporate Shuffle or ... Players try to get rid of their cards as fast as possible. The first person to get rid of their cards becomes Head of the Line in the next hand. Differences include two wild cards, which can be paired with any card, or if both in one hand, can used before the game begins to reorder the table completely.

The card themes are based on the staff and customers of Gary's Games and Hobbies in Seattle, WA. The game was released to celebrate the store's twentieth anniversary in October of 2010.
categories: Card Game

name: Blaze The Cat: Fire & Safety Rescue Game
description:
This is an educational game designed for children ages 5 and older. The game "teaches children and families about different types of fire equipment and their uses. Additionally and most importantly it shows that it is always better to be a Team Player."

Each kid is represented by a Blaze The Cat firefighter token. The board represents a 10 story building with 8 rooms or stairways on each floor. The players race to the roof and then jump into the rescue helicopter. The first player to reach the top is the winner but all of the children board the chopper at the end of the game... nobody dies.

The cards are intended to teach lessons about courtesy, safety, and the things firefighters do in an emergency. Players roll dice and draw cards to move during a turn. Some reading will be required unless a parent or older child reads the cards.

Includes 4 tokens, 70 cards, a die, a colorful board, and the rules.
categories: Children's Game
publishers: Blaze The Cat and His Firefighter Support Team

name: Dinofroz Survivors
description:
Two teams of dinosaurs battle each other. Battle occurs when two dinosaurs are next to each other. Then the players spin tops to see who wins the battle. When one side is completely eliminated the game is over.

The dinosaurs are collectable and randomly sealed in eggs.
categories: Children's Game, Collectible Components, Miniatures

name: Skulduggery Pleasant Game Cards
description:
From the back of the slipcase:
"Challenge your friends to supernatural duels with exclusive Skulduggery Pleasant game cards! Pit your wits and use battle skills to fight with characters old and new, including unseen secret info on villains from the third Skulduggery adventure!"

Comes in a slipcase "Battle Pack" with a trade paperback of the first Skulduggery Pleasant book. Made for sale in the UK.

From the "How to Play" card:

"2-4 players

1. Shuffle and deal all cards face down in stacks.
2. Each player holds their cards so that they can only see the first card in their stack.
3. The player to the left of the dealer chooses a category from their upturned card to do battle with e.g. Adept Magic.
4. The other players take turns to read out the score for this category on their upturned card.
5. The player with the highest score wins this round and places all the upturned cards including their own to the bottom of the pile.
6. The winner then chooses a category from their next card to start a new round.
NB. If two or more cards in a round share the top score then all the cards are placed in the middle and a new round is started (by the same player as before). The winner of this round takes the cards in the middle too.
7. The person with all the cards at the end of the game is the winner.
Optional extra rule: Once a player is down to only three cards, they may look at all three and choose which to play."

Art by Tom Percival.
categories: Card Game, Novel-based

name: CrystalicuM: Kryształowa Gra Karciana (second edition)
description:
“There is no doubt that the simultaneous deaths of the personal doctor of the Empire’s ambassador to the City of Gnomes, a dwarven merchant named Nuñez y Carazil, who owned a canton in Amidawa, and Timur ibn Sallah, an astonian burglar serving a sentence in the Morning City have not occurred by pure chance. As we will show here, though nothing obvious points to that conclusion, the three were acquaintances and exchanged coded letters often. Whoever decided to eliminate them, not only learned of this connection, but also had the resources to strike in three different places of the Universe at once. We know then, that we are dealing with two covert organisations: one to which the deceased belonged to, and another which performed the executions. We also know that at least one of them does not stop short of murder.
- Aldobrandino di Gato Nero, “The Chronicle of the War of Shadows”

CrystalicuM - Krzysztalowa Gra Karciana (Polish for Crystal Card Game, abbreviated KGK) is a Polish CCG, set in a 'fantasy/ space opera/ steampunk' universe and with anime/manga like art. The universe is also developed in a Polish role-playing game of the same name.

In the Known Universe there are many secret conflicts, wars and alliances. Secret brotherhoods fight each other, and for them, interstellar powers are only a tokens in the eternal game. The fate of the Universe and its unaware inhabitants rests upon you.

The Second Edition started in november 2010.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Science Fiction

name: Objection! Justice Duel
description:
Game description from the publisher:

In Objection! Justice Duel, each player plays the role of a lawyer who tries desperately, trial after trial, to acquire more and more fame. In each trial, the players try to overcome the opponent by getting the most valuable combination of cards, using the points at their disposal to fish or to reveal new cards to bluff or to block the opponent's shouting of "Objection!"

Who will be the most famous lawyer at the end of the game?
categories: Bluffing, Card Game
mechanics: Action Points, Betting and Bluffing, Set Collection

name: CONTACT! The Canadian Army Tactical Training Wargame
description:
User's summary, partly paraphrased from the introduction:

CONTACT! is a set of tactical wargaming rules developed by the Canadian Army Combat Training Centre as a training aid. It is based on a simplified version of the "Wargames Rules for Armoured Warfare 1950-1985", published by the Wargames Research Group (WRG) in 1979. It is played on a terrain model using miniatures representing single vehicles, infantry sections, and crew-served weapons. Players adopt the roles of commanders of platoon or company sized groups. The game requires at least a neutral player in the role of controller, who sets the scenario, supervises play and resolves disputes. Combat is resolved by percentile dice rolls on probability tables, modified by range, suppression status, movement and terrain.

Editor John Curry added some weapon tables for the British and American Army, and additional information and order of battles for Canadian, Warsaw Pact and British forces.
categories: Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: Terra Shrinka
description:
Terra Shrinka is a cooperative dam-building survival game for 1-4 players. Terra Shrinka has a unique lunar tide system that controls the water and will erode the island if you don't work together to scout out the island, gather resources, and build dams fast enough.

THE STORY SO FAR

On a South Pacific flight your plane is struck by lighting and makes an emergency landing on a small desert island. The good news is that everyone survived the landing, the bad news is that the tides are rising and the island is flooding. It's up to the brave passengers to step forward and bring order to the chaos. You survived the crash, now can you survive the flood? The very earth is shrinking around you! Can you dam the flood?

THE OBJECTIVE

Dam the flood by creating an unbroken chain of dams from one board edge to the other and protect the crash-site in the process!

HOW THE GAME PLAYS

The game starts with the board taking its turn. The board’s turn is broken into five phases:

1. Move Moon Tracker
2. Add Flood Cube(s)
3. Roll Moon Die that matches current Moon Phase
4. Draw card if “N” or “S” is rolled.
5. Move Flood water and resolve damage

After the water does a good job of destroying board squares, it is the players’ turn. Each player starts with their Team Leader in the Crash Site. During the players’ turn, they do the following:

1. Explore and Move
2. Create
3. Transfer
4. Set Dams

Each player has a starting character. Are you the ren-faire blacksmith, or are you the bag lady? No matter whom, it is each team’s job to explore this uncharted little island. The survivors find food to bribe more recruits off the plane. They make networks of people to transfer gathered goods. And finally, they create and set dams to stop the water. This requires lots of communication and teamwork to protect your Crash Site and stop the water from spreading any more. If your Crash Site is destroyed, you lose. Otherwise, keep track of how many squares were destroyed when you finally blocked off the flood and try to do better next time. There are additional scenarios to add replay value and ensure that you want to come back for more.
categories: Adventure, Exploration
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Enclosure, Modular Board, Network and Route Building, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: I Jotunheimen
description:
The game board is a map with hiking routes of Jotunheimen, a mountainous area in Norway. 2-6 players roll for a start position and begin the hiking race for the mount "Galdhøpiggen", the highest mountain in Norway.

The die is six-sided, but instead of the normal, it has the values 1V, 2H, 3V, 4H, T and U. These are abbreviations for 1 Left, 2 Right, 3 Left, 4 Right, Fog and Stormy weather.
The players move the number on the die, and when comming to crossroads they must go either left or right depending on the die. If they roll T they must pass a turn, and when U is rolled, they must immediately move to the nearest tourist cabin.

Whenever a player lands on a spot with a number, an event occurs for that player, like "At Hæranåse: You've got blisters. Pass one turn", or "Over Friken: You are in good shape, Get another roll".

The publisher Damm's game No. 208.
categories: Travel

name: Fyrdwisa
description:
In Fyrdwisa, players take on the role of an Anglo-Saxon war leader seeking dominion over their enemies on the battlefields of the dark ages. They make use of strategically deployed armies and barricades, occupy neutral cities to control their resources, and fight their way across the battlefield to capture their opponent's capital.

Fyrdwisa is a turn-based strategy game in which players spend action points and reveal resource cards to perform actions. Depending on the neutral cities they control, players receive between 1 and 6 action points each turn. Players may save action points from turn to turn (up to 12 points) to perform special actions or execute sudden military maneuvers. Depending on the number of players, there are up to 4 neutral cities for players to attack. Each city's resource is revealed when it is first occupied. The game includes cards for 10 possible city resources (which are assigned randomly) so each game plays out differently. When attacked, neutral cities may "bribe" players into retreating by providing them with a single-use special resource card.

Fyrdwisa is played on a cloth game board printed with a hexagonal battlefield. Each hexagon is divided into six triangles, in which players place small glass game pieces. Action point counters are printed in the corners of the game board, to assist in tracking available points each turn. City resources are printed on heavy stock paper cards.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Exploration, Medieval
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven

name: In Hoc Signo Vinces: The Campaign for Rome, 312 AD
description:
In Hoc Signo Vinces: The Campaign for Rome, 312 AD is actually 2 games . One game uses an area map to portray the campaign fought in northern and central Italy between the forces of Maxentius and Constantine. Battles between forces in the same area are resolved on a separate "battle board". Rules include omens, differing types of forces, as well as what the Eastern Emperor, Licinius is up to.
The other game is on the climatic battle of the campaign, Milvian Bridge. This uses a hex map and a separate rules section.

Components for IHSV include two 11 by 17 maps, 288 unmounted single-sided counters 1 8.5 by 11 battle board, two sets of rules (16 pages for the campaign game, 6 pages for the Milvian Bridge battle game) and 4 pages of charts/tables/tracks.
categories: Ancient, Wargame

name: Top Cat: The Santa Claws Scam
description:
A Christmas-themed Board Game for children, based on Hanna-Barbera's Top Cat TV series.

"It's Christmas, and Top Cat and the gang are on the look out for some easy money to buy the last prize hamper in the shop. Top Cat's plan is to dress up as Santa, and stand in front of shop entrances collecting money. After all, everybody would like to help a poor hungry kitty at Christmas time!"

Each player controls a member of Top Cat's gang. Players start the game with 3 cards representing a Santa costume (Beard, Hat and Cloak), but can lose and gain these items of clothing as a consequence of various game events. To collect cash, a player must be in the possession of a full Santa outfit and end their turn on a money square (shop entrance).

Top Cat's nemesis - Officer Dibble - moves around the board after each player's turn. If Officer Dibble lands on a player, the player loses all of the cash that they're currently carrying. Cash can, however, be safely deposited in the player's home square (a trash can).

Several event cards allow the players to attempt to "spoof" another player. "Spoofing" involves a bluffing/guessing game in which players have to guess how many coins the other player is concealing in his hands. The winner takes the loser's cash, and can also steal an item from the loser's Santa Costume.

The first player to collect 10 coins and purchase the prize hamper from the food shop wins the game.
categories: Children's Game

name: King Square  Game
description:
Object Of The Game:

The object of the game is for a player, or partners, to be the first to complete the four corners of a square of any size with pegs of his own color. Such a square is called a King-Square. The first player, or partners, to complete five such King-Squares have won the game.

Instructions For Two Players:

Opposing players use different sets of colored pegs. Players take turns alternately in playing a peg in any unoccupied position of the playing field. They continue to do so until one player has completed a the four corners of a square with pegs of his own color. As soon as a King-Square has been made the successful player records the square on his score board. All the pegs are then removed from the playing field and the loser starts play to build another King-Square. This process is repeated after each square is completed until one player has build five such squares with pegs of his own color. The first player to to do so has won the game.

Building King-Square

The first player to complete the four corners of a square with pegs of his own color has a King-Square. It makes no difference how many pegs of his own color, or of his opponent, are inside this square - or on the sides of the square - or in between his pegs on the four corners of the square - all that matters is that all the pegs on the four corners of the square are pegs of his own color.

Squares made at an angle do not count. A King-Square must be parallel to the sides of the playing field and the rows and columns of holes. A square must be made up of four sides of equal length. A square is a figure having four equal sides and four right angles. A rectangle is not a square.

Partnership play - four players

As in Bridge, four players can play as two pairs of partners, each pair sitting opposite each other. Each pair uses pegs of the same color, dividing the pegs between them at the start of the game. All four players take turns alternately in placing their pegs, going clockwise around the table. As soon as a King-Square has been made it is recorded and a new square is started. As with two players, the game is won by the partners who are first to complete five King-Squares.
categories: Abstract Strategy

name: Atomic Cafe 1957
description:
Theme: 1957 is drawing to a close. The U.S.S.R. launched a multi-stage ballistic missile earlier in the year and the U.S., not wanting to fall behind in the missile race, launches its first ICBM on December 17th. Soon the world is blasted to ruins and only small pockets, isolated from the destruction and ensuing radioactive fallout, prove habitable over the long term. And between those pockets, battles rage between gangs of survivors (The 8th Avenue Greasers, The Michigan State Bowling League, and others) and rogue military units. All of them seeking food, fuel, or a place free of radiation.

Game Play: Players compete and combat for possession of the remaining resources among the nuclear wastes. Player activate their gangs by random card activation. Encounter markers are used to designate various sites to search. Combat is fast and bloody between the players, or with wandering with RadZombies, Mutated men, animals and insects. Final victory is determined by the exiting of these few precious items off the board.
categories: Book

name: Ambit
description: AMBIT® has all the elements players like in a board game. You control your own fate. No early eliminations. Players decide on each turn whether to roll the dice, pick a card or play a card from their hand! No two games are ever the same! Every player has a chance to win until the very end. AMBIT® will provide hours of fun as you try to outwit and outmaneuver your opponents. Decision making is key on every move. AMBIT® is played with 2 to 6 players, individually or in teams. The box says ages 12 to adult, however, it can be played by anyone who can read and reason. AMBIT® was entirely made in Buffalo (NY), with the exception of pawns and dice. They were acquired from a U.S. company who made the pawns but not the dice. Estimated play time: 30 to 90 minutes.
categories: Party Game

name: Terra Kids: Wo leben Tiere?
description:
Terra Kids - Where do the animals live?

Are kangaroos from Australia? Do penguins live in Africa? You will find the answers to these questions and many more in the game. Set off on an exciting journey and learn with Terra Kids about the natural habitats of different animals.

The game includes rules in German, English, French, Italian, Spanish and Dutch.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Educational, Environmental

name: Metapontum Peace Chess
description:
Metapontum is a cooperative abstract strategy game created and promoted by Dutch designer Hans Theo Frenkel and the foundation he created, for the purpose of promoting world peace. It is played on an 8x8 hexagonal board with 16 pieces on each side, that have movement very similar to those in Chess, and are abstract as in Chess. The goal of Metapontum is for both sides to exchange their pieces from their chosen opening setup to their chosen end setup in a minimum amount of moves. On every turn, a player can either move one of his pieces or exchange one of his pieces with one of his opponent's, as long as his piece has line of sight to the other.

Frenkel's web site sells various game boards made out of either cardboard, wood or stone. Frenkel claims that all games are produced under fair trade practices.
categories: Abstract Strategy

name: 1066: Battle of Hastings Card Game
description:
It is October 14th 1066 - late afternoon. On Senlac Hill near Hastings the Saxon Army under King Harold II is fighting the invading Normans under William, Duke of Normandy. The battle is not going well for William. Twice he has attacked and twice been repelled and it looks as if he cannot break Harold’s Lines.
He calls his nobles to him and promises them gold and land if they will defeat the Saxons and Kill Harold.

It is time for his Counts to make a name for themselves.

The game is played in Player turns which proceed clockwise from the start player until the game ends.During the game the active player is the ACTIVE NORMAN and will use his Normans to attack the Saxons. One of the other players will be the ACTIVE SAXON and will do his best to defeat the efforts of the ACTIVE NORMAN.

Cards represent the Saxons and the Normans and show via red blood drop the number of wounds they have. Blue circles show how many fatigue points they can take. Gold number is value if defeated by a Norman. Green Diamond is speed. The sword and Shield symbols show the number of Attack and Defence cards they draw

Combat is conducted by playing an ATTACK card which might be blocked by a defence card or cause 1 or more wounds.

The objective of the game is for the Players to defeat as many Saxons as they can whilst defeating the efforts of the other players. The game ends when Harold is killed or the NOrmans are exhausted.
categories: Card Game, Medieval

name: Монопол
description:
This russian children's game is very similar to Monopoly.

The game board consists of thirty-five spaces. Twenty-two of them are properties (hotel, bakery, clinic, planetarium, etc.), other - special spaces with different functions (+500, bathhouse, lottery, cockroach racing, etc.) Most of special spaces are mini gamblings with dice rolling.

The object of the game is to become the wealthiest player.

Contents:
- 1 gameboard
- 6 pawns
- 1 dice
- colored tokens in 6 colors
- money
categories: Economic
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Chametz: The Search Is On!
description:
The word "chametz" is Hebrew and refers to the food items and derivatives that are prohibited during the week of the Jewish holiday Passover (usually bread and other items containing five prohibited grains: barley, wheat, oat, rye and spelt). Egregious examples of chametz include pizza, donuts, cookies, cupcakes, pretzels, and crackers. "Chametz: The Search is On!" is played similarly to "Clue" but instead of deducing a murder, the players must determine which character left which item of chametz in which room. It's especially appropriate because Jewish law requires families to search their home and clean it of all chametz before Passover begins.

The board is a blueprint of a house with six rooms (kitchen, bedroom, dining room, living room, office and garage). There are also six items of food and six characters.

Eighteen cards are included (one for each character, food and room). After separating the cards into the 3 categories and secretly hiding one character, one food and one room in the small envelope provided, the remaining cards are shuffled and then dealt out to the entire group, clockwise, until all cards are gone. Players may begin in any room as long as they choose it before seeing their cards. They take turns rolling a six-sided die to determine how far they can walk around the perimeter of the home (with entrances off the main spaces).

Upon entering a room, players may make a guess as to the hidden person, food and room. The player to their left may prove them wrong by showing a card in their hand that matches one of the items in the guess. If that player has no matches, the guess goes to the next person. If nobody has a match, the player can check the hidden cards to see if they're right.

Players do not have to write with pen or pencil (another prohibition for Jews on the Sabbath and Holidays) and instead place cardboard markers in a noteboard with 18 slots (one for each item).

The cardboard markers can be placed in the slot in such a way as to "point" left, right or up, and may be used to remind yourself who showed you that particular item.

There are 4 mandatory "Question Squares" on the board and 4 optional ones. When landing on these squares, the player is read a question from the stack of Question Cards based on another roll of the die (each Question Card has True/False, Multiple Choice and Fill-in-the-Blank versions of the question). A roll of 1 or 2 gets the easier True-False version, and 5 or 6 gets the hardest Fill-in-the-Blank version. The questions pertain to Passover and Jewish History.

After answering correctly, the player may immediately jump to any room on the board and make a guess. There are no secret passageways between rooms otherwise.

First player to guess the hidden character, food and room wins. To play with 2 players, one card is placed face down in each room before dealing the cards out. So when entering a room, the player may choose to make a guess or look at the face-down card (it's essentially a 3rd player who shows one of their cards when you enter each room).
categories: Educational, Murder/Mystery, Religious

name: Biruda
description:
UNRELEASED GAME



Note that all details for this game are subjects to change.




Biruda is a city building game for 2-4 Architects. Each one of you has to build total, 5 buildings in the 3 different sectors of the board (Mainframe). The Mainframe is divided in the Grey, the Red and the Gold Sector. You have to build 2 Constructions in each sector and 1 in the Gold and last one. The Buildings come to your possession through the Architectonic Plans. Each Sector hides unique constructions but traps too as well as it offers a variety of choices.

Your rival Architects won't allow you to reach the gold and they will use all the means of the game such as the Hazard Cards. Using them, can seriously damage your constructions. On the other hand, the Mainframe wouldn't let you exposed, to them. That's why it offers the Construction Assurances. Thanks to these cards you will be protected, however, up to a point. Still, your rivals can use the Grids, obstacles that they place on the Mainframe and specifically in the area where you build and can delay you a lot. Place your pawn on the Pavement (outer board), draw your Plans, buy raw materials, hire the necessary Groups of Workers, get the License of your Construction and start building. But be careful, if you cheat, then the Construction Inspector will lead you out of the Mainframe. Since you complete your building, you collect a standard payment as well as different bonuses matching the different board-combinations where the Mainframe offers to you.

Maybe this game seems easy and known but Biruda offers innovative mechanisms where you will meet duing the play. To prove yourself among the other and be the Master Architect you have to move with caution. The Pavement around gives to all the chance to draw different card sets and these cards will be proved veru useful during your work. Still this game differs a lot thanks to its variations such the board pieces of the Mainframe where you can connect them in different ways and reform the whole city. Among the Hazards, there are Earthquake Cards and based on their effects you can change totally the game. The most important here is that even if a rival Architect has managed to reach the Gold Sector and you are far behind, well with a single move you can restore the balance and be the winner.

THE MAINFRAME IS NOW OPEN!
categories: Card Game, City Building

name: Kotipihan Eläimet
description:
From the publisher
In the three games of the Backyard Nature series, the player will be introduced to nature’s creatures by being challenged to recognise them. The attractive picture cards portray common animals in a realistic manner, and the player must name them correctly. The game can also be played outdoors – finding the corresponding animals in nature will help the learning process!
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Educational, Environmental

name: Whirred PLAY
description:
Whirred PLAY™ - ‘The Holy Grail of Family Board Games’

What is Whirred PLAY™?

Whirred PLAY™ is a unique word game designed so that anyone can win regardless of their vocabulary and designed so that everyone can play together no matter the composition or size of the family or social group.

Reason Whirred PLAY™ was Developed

Whirred PLAY™ was developed because existing board games did not satisfy a need to be able to play a game with the whole family where everyone was challenged and mentally stimulated, but where everyone had an equal chance of winning. Games of chance such as ‘snakes and ladders’ and ‘ludo’ can be won by anyone, but they do not offer a lot in the way of mental stimulation for those taking part and soon the thrill of being able to play a board game together as a family diminishes.
More intricate family board games such as ‘Scrabble’ and ‘Monopoly’ do provide the level of mental stimulation required. However, one is much more likely to win these games if one has more life experience (to be able to play strategically) and more education (knowledgeable about a subject). As a consequence younger family members, or those with self perceived lower life skills, shy away from playing these games because they always expect to get beaten.

In order to encourage these groups of people to join in, adults will often have to play below their best to give them a chance to win and to maintain their interest in playing the game. Whilst this is fun for a while, it soon becomes difficult for the adult to gain enough satisfaction from playing the game from the levels of satisfaction achieved by seeing their offspring’s delight at winning.

How is Whirred PLAY™ Unique?

So Whirred PLAY™ enables everyone to play a game at their own level of skill and strategy, but whatever their level this does not determine whether or not they are more or less likely to win. Whirred PLAY™ is open for any number of players to join in at the same time, so unlike when playing ‘Scrabble’ (maximum four players) or ‘Monopoly’ (maximum six players), no member of the family or social group need sit on the sidelines. Everyone can join in the fun.

Additionally, Whirred PLAY™ is designed so that at all times in the game everyone always has a chance of winning, no matter their position on the board, until the eventual winner crosses the finishing line. In games such as ‘Scrabble’ and ‘Monopoly’ there will come a point where it is obvious certain players are not going to win. Some participants may decide that they will leave the game at this point and that can have a detrimental effect on the pleasure of all parties involved in playing the game. This also may become a hindrance for future participation from those who have departed early. A special feature of Whirred PLAY™ is an element of the game called ‘Pare Up’, especially designed to provide ample opportunity for players to bring the leader back to the chasing pack.

Another element of Whirred PLAY™ that ensures maximum interest from all parties is that any particular game should last no more than 30 minutes. ‘Scrabble’ and ‘Monopoly, in particular, can run on for long periods of time and this can be a barrier for those with shorter attention spans, usually children, to want to take part. And with over 440 cards in Whirred PLAY™, there is very little repetitiveness, as a typical game usually only utilises 30 to 40 cards.

Additionally, the game play of Whirred PLAY™ is designed so that everyone is participating all at the same time. No-one has to wait for any one particular player to finish their turn, which in some other family board games can often be quite a long time.

Whirred PLAY™ is Educational

As Whirred PLAY™ is based on the simple premise of spelling everyday words that just happen to be homophones, a key stage two literacy curriculum topic, it has high appeal amongst both parents and teachers as an excellent fun method of teaching children this difficult subject. Children will want to play Whirred PLAY™ because of all of the elements of inclusivity and equality listed above, and parents will be delighted that a game they want to play offers more than just a fun half hour.

Schools can utilise Whirred PLAY™ in formal teaching classes due to its all inclusive nature and the ability for the whole class to participate in it, with an equal chance of winning it, at the same time regardless of its size or composition. The competitive nature of Whirred PLAY™ especially appeals to boys, traditionally a more difficult group of students to enthuse about learning how to spell.

Whirred PLAY™ - ‘The Holy Grail of Family Board Games’

So Whirred PLAY™ really is a board game like no other. Everyone can take part, everyone has an equal chance of winning, everyone can apply their own level of strategy and utilise their own level of life experience, everyone is involved at all times, everyone can win at all times during the game, no-one gets bored, everyone gets educated and everyone has fun.
categories: Word Game

name: Your Word
description:
A quick, humorous card game of words and imagination.

Your Word is a game in which players create their own fictional, made-up words (using the cards in their hand) to fit the theme of the round. The players’ cards contain word fragments that are used in many real English words today. Each round, a new theme sentence is revealed and the players must complete the sentence with a phrase that includes their new made-up word.

The key skill in the game is for a player to create an entertaining word from their cards which allows them to complete the theme sentence with flair and imagination, in order to impress the judge and win the round. Points are also awarded to second and third place depending upon the number of players.

The normal goal of the game is to have been awarded more points than the opposing players after one full round in which all players have had the opportunity to judge once.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Word Game

name: FQ3
description:
"FQ3" is a board game that recreates the world of the car races. With a mixture of strategy, action, control of risk, and some touches of role, FQ3 represents a real way (and funny too), all that happens inside and outside of the tracks.

"FQ3" has 3 difficulty levels of rules to satisfy all kind of players;

- BASIC RULES: Aimed at casual and undemanding gamers.

- ADVANCED RULES: For fans of race games. These rules are more realistic, and involved all sorts of factors: such as types of tires, fuel loads, setting the car, kers, yellow flag, Safety Car, moral of drivers and injuries, etc.

- MANAGER MODE: Only for those who drink gasoline! In this game mode, in addition to the role of pilot, you will assume the role of team manager. You will manage the economy, hiring drivers, sponsors, engineers, desing the car and evolve it. The years pass and drivers will gain experience and they will improve their skills.

SUMMARY OF GAMEPLAY: The Friday of the GP, the player must decide the strategy (number of stops, tires, and fuel load).

On Saturday, will be held the pole position, it follows a mathematical operation involving various modifiers (skills of the pilot, car performance, fuel load, tires, moral, blunders, and a roll of 1d20).

The race takes place the Sunday.
The circuit is composed of squares. The cars will go moving by circuit as many squares as the speed (gear dependent) of your car.
When the cars reach the corners, the drivers must brake and accelerate. Brakes and accelerates with a d100. Drivers have an ability to Brake and Accelerate that used to take curves (higher or lower depending on driver).
These skills will be modified by the fuel load, tire types, and how close you decide to brake and accelerate.
The risk you take in the curves is important; you can take away your opponents, but be careful!, fail brake roll or acceleration roll will damage your car.

The game stands on four pillars:
The driver, the car, the pit stop mechanics, and the circuit.
Each of them has many different skills, qualities or details that make it different from the others.

This is a brief summary of how to play. There are many and funny rules, such as kers, spin, overtaking, blunders, drivers' virtues, drive's defects, safety car,etc.
categories: Racing, Sports
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simulation, Variable Player Powers
